title: ft 21 feb 94 mirror group lifts bid for independent
body: the consortium backed by mirror group newspapers yesterday increased its bid for newspaper publishing owners of the independent and independent on sunday in an effort to gain a majority stake in the company the bid was raised from 261 6p to 350p a share matching the sum paid earlier this month by mr tony o reilly s independent newspapers of ireland for 24 99 per cent of the company the increased bid values newspaper publishing at pounds 73 65m the consortium controls nearly 48 per cent of newspaper publishing and hopes the new offer will enable it to secure more than 50 per cent apart from mgn the consortium includes newspaper publishing s two largest existing shareholders el pais of spain and la repubblica of italy and a group which founded the newspapers led by mr andreas whittam smith editor in chief newspaper publishing said yesterday a committee of the board made up of independent directors would discuss the improved bid today and there would be a full board meeting on thursday the consortium hoped the offer would be recommended with a view to ending as soon as possible the present damaging uncertainty about the company s future it said the independent directors had indicated the price was acceptable however it said its offer would be formally rejected because it would not undertake to maintain the offer on the same terms in the event of the bid being referred to and cleared by the monopolies and mergers commission mr michael heseltine the trade and industry secretary is considering a request from the consortium that it should be allowed to acquire a controlling interest without an mmc inquiry he could agree to this if he is satisfied the newspapers are not economic as a going concern he has set a deadline of march 3 for comment on the proposal mr o reilly could now attempt to increase his stake beyond 24 99 per cent 25 per cent is the trigger for an mmc referral on the grounds that an inquiry is now in any case under consideration it is understood mr o reilly has been told by the independent directors the consortium bid will ultimately succeed if he fails to make a full bid merely raising his stake to 30 per cent would not solve the company s problems long term he has been told the national union of journalists branch at the newspapers said it could still not support the mgn consortium bid because of the likely loss of up to 250 jobs and the destruction of editorial independence

title: ft 21 feb 94 postal workers reject productivity deal union fears royal mail may now impose changes
body: britain s postal workers have decisively rejected a national productivity plan to improve the royal mail s efficiency and make it more commercial in preparation for its eventual privatisation in a secret postal ballot they voted against the deal against the advice of their union the union of communication workers only 33 194 supported the productivity plan while 37 667 rejected it a total of 71 444 union members out of 128 874 returned completed ballot papers union leaders deeply embarrassed by the rejection are today due to meet royal mail executives to discuss what they can do next mr alan johnson the ucw s general secretary said yesterday we need a period of calm reflection at national level the ucw leadership has been working very closely with the post office to make the organisation more commercial the union s national leadership has been willing to co operate with the introduction of more flexible working practices in sorting offices and mail delivery the productivity deal would have created a framework for local deals to introduce more flexible shift patterns and working practices in sorting offices in the aftermath of the unexpected defeat union officials fear the royal mail management may impose changes without union consent in breach of national agreements with the ucw this could involve the unilateral withdrawal by management of a number of interim productivity agreements which came into force six years ago ucw leaders are concerned that as a result of the deal s defeat the royal mail will also refuse to negotiate any further on the introduction of a shorter working week mr johnson said initial reports from the union s branches around the country suggested many postal workers had found the proposed productivity scheme too complicated and half baked the ucw hopes more talks can improve the deal to make it more attractive under the negotiated deal that was rejected nearly half the postal workers would have benefited financially from an increase in minimum pay rates on top of the basic 1 5 per cent pay rise they would have received a further 1 5 to 1 6 per cent by agreeing to the productivity changes this would have ensured that the lowest paid workers in the royal mail received an increase in their basic pay of twice the current rate of inflation

title: ft 21 feb 94 nato lifts threat of early air strikes un finds substantial withdrawal of serb guns west warns ultimatum remains
body: tension over bosnia eased early today as the united nations said nato air strikes against the bosnian serbs around sarajevo were unnecessary at this stage but western officials warned that the threat of air strikes remained unless the serbs continued to observe the nato ultimatum issued earlier this month soon after the deadline for ending the serb artillery siege of the bosnian capital expired at midnight the un said there had been substantial withdrawal or regrouping of the serb heavy weapons mr yasushi akashi the un special envoy in former yugoslavia said on the basis of the information available to me and pending further verification i have decided that it is not necessary at this stage for me to request nato to use air power in washington the white house said all bosnian serb heavy guns around sarajevo had been neutralised or soon should be as a result un and nato commanders had concluded no air strikes were necessary at this time a senior official said mr manfred worner nato secretary general said there had been effective compliance with the nato demand to remove heavy weapons more than 20km from sarajevo or put them under un control under pain of air strikes nato s resolve to end the shelling of sarajevo does not end today he added we shall continue to verify compliance we will remain vigilant the military threat receded after the nato alliance had assembled in italy and the adriatic sea the largest forces of air power since the gulf war the moslem led bosnian government yesterday urged nato to go ahead with air strikes against the bosnian serbs it accused the un of conniving with the serbs to avert air strikes in a bid to reassure the moslems general sir michael rose the un commander in bosnia warned that if there were any breaches of the nato ultimatum i will have no hesitation in calling air strikes in relaxed remarks before the deadline gen rose appeared concerned to defuse tension asked where he would be at the midnight deadline he told reporters in bed pentagon officials said that poor weather made it difficult to determine immediately how many guns might still be within 20km of sarajevo air strikes were unlikely to be ordered before a complete assessment could be made in the daylight today they added but us officials warned that the nato ultimatum was open ended and that air strikes could be launched at any time if the serbs did not continue to comply they also said western allies would this week discuss expanding the sarajevo ultimatum to ease the plight of other besieged bosnian cities mr warren christopher us secretary of state said the next step is to consider whether other places in bosnia should have a comparable treatment including the towns of srbrenica and gorazde shortly before the midnight deadline 400 russian un peacekeeping troops moved into sarajevo to act as a buffer between moslem led forces in the capital and the serbs who have been besieging the city for 22 months the soldiers in a convoy of 70 armoured vehicles trucks and jeeps were moved from croatia and will be followed by another 400 men from russia mr worner thanked russia for its role in bosnia in the past few days when it lent its weight to secure bosnian serb agreement to withdraw heavy weapons the just and lasting peace that we must now try to achieve in bosnia involves close russian involvement he added we all must try to maintain the momentum and reflect on further steps president bill clinton phoned russian president boris yeltsin yesterday and told him he was encouraged by serb efforts to comply with the nato ultimatum a us official said mr vitaly churkin russia s deputy foreign minister and moscow s special envoy in former yugoslavia warned earlier that nato s partnership for peace agreements with former warsaw pact states in eastern europe could be one casualty of any air strike the point here is not air strikes it is peace he said as the west seeks ways to capitalise on the ceasefire around sarajevo and move the peace process forward mr douglas hurd british foreign secretary will today hold talks with mr alain juppe his french counterpart senior officials from the european union the us russia and the un are due to meet tomorrow in bonn mr christopher said that finding a settlement which met the reasonable requirements of the bosnian moslems was a high priority and that the apparent success of nato s new resolve over sarajevo would boost peace talks removal of the serb artillery eases but does not end the siege of sarajevo and its 380 000 inhabitants serb forces still control all access to the city although un troops are monitoring the latest ceasefire which has restored some degree of normality further reports page 2

title: ft 21 feb 94 financial markets braced for further turbulence
body: international financial markets look set for another bout of turbulence today after the sell off that caused heavy falls in us and european bond and equity markets late last friday one senior marketmaker in uk equities said yesterday that the ft se 100 the london market s leading stocks could probably be marked down by as much as 60 points at the opening to try to head off any attempted selling by the big institutions he said that 3 355 on the ft se 100 would be a benchmark for market sentiment if it closes above 3 355 we should stabilise the ft se 100 closed at 3 382 6 last friday wall street is closed today presidents day last week s sell off came as bond dealers took fright at talk of exceptionally heavy selling of international bonds by some big us hedge funds which are involved in aggressive short term trading but seek to offset exposure to changes in market rates this was compounded by worries about what mr alan greenspan us federal reserve chairman will say to congress tomorrow in a review of monetary policy asian centres will provide the first pointers to international market performance today in tokyo shares edged lower in thin morning trading with the nikkei average down 18 at midday hong kong stocks were sharply down in early trade mr nick knight analyst at nomura the stockbroker said the hong kong market is a critical and sensitive indicator of us money flows if hong kong is down 200 points we ll have a manageable fall in london but if it is significantly larger than that then it could be serious global investor page 22 currency markets page 23 international bonds page 24 equity markets page 25

title: ft 19 feb 94 outdoors ft round the world ski expedition
body: more than 25 media correspondents crammed into a valentine s day news conference at breckenridge to mark the expedition s first 50 days plus arnie wilson s 50th birthday wilson who is suffering frostbite on his nose reports we were forced to ski after dark at keystone to keep up our record of skiing every day in 1994 to clock up more miles we spent tuesday skiing madly and with the help of night skiing we managed more than 30 000 vertical feet in a day more than the height of everest you could win a skiing holiday for two or runner up prizes of malt whisky by entering the competition which appeared in weekend ft on february 5 copies available from the ft shop tel 071 873 3324

title: ft 19 feb 94 civil service fast stream entry system reviewed
body: the government is reviewing one of the cornerstones of the british civil service the fast stream entry system that assures a glittering career for an elite of young high flyers the cabinet office said yesterday that the review would look at the strategic question of whether the civil service needs a fast stream system at all for nearly 140 years the fast stream has picked out a small group of civil servants at the start of their careers and virtually ensured that they are whitehall mandarins about 20 years later the system has been regularly attacked for ensuring that the civil service is run by a like minded group of white middle class males educated at oxford and cambridge universities mr william waldegrave the public service minister said in a parliamentary written answer that the review would be completed by june the review follows calls from inside and outside whitehall for changes to the top structure of the civil service to bring it into line with the management reforms of the past six years the creation of executive agencies to deliver central government services has led ministers to look for private sector skills in those who run them a recent whitehall report into career management said that the fast stream system could encourage the worst aspects of elitism and without care might perpetuate a set of skills more suitable to the past than the future mr john garrett labour mp for norwich south and a former member of the commons treasury and civil service committee said the announcement was the first time ministers had admitted that the system needed changing a crack has appeared in the facade he added he said that civil service reforms could have a big impact on elite career management in the private sector cabinet office staff were more reserved about the announcement an official said it shows we are a good sensible employer and this is a regular review of whether our recruitment is up to best practice the fast stream system is administered by recruitment and assessment services on behalf of the civil service commissioners

title: ft 19 feb 94 data chief named
body: mrs elizabeth france was yesterday named as data protection registrar in succession to mr eric howe who is to retire this year mrs france who joined the home office in 1971 is head of its information and pay services division she is a member of the committee for the co ordination of computerisation in the criminal justice system

body: the us has decided to restore senior level contacts with new zealand thawing a seven year chill between the two nations over new zealand s ban on visits by nuclear warships writes george graham in washington us defence obligations under the anzus treaty will remain suspended

title: ft 19 feb 94 portuguese telecom merger
body: portugal has launched plans to merge its two state run telecommunications companies telecom portugal and teledifusora de portugal tdp and absorb semi private radio marconi the finance ministry announced yesterday ap writes from lisbon the new group will be called portugal telecom the merger anticipates the eventual privatisation of portugal telecom after november 1994 tlp currently controls telecommunications for lisbon and porto while telecom handles long distance mainland and offshore traffic within portugal and to europe marconi provides intercontinental satellite and cable services
