title: ft 10 mar 94 management marketing and advertising hard sell for a new british cheese churnton s confident launch into the mass market
body: you can almost hear the hoots of derision from across the channel at the news that an exciting new british cheese was launched this week yet after the much publicised demise of lymeswold the imitation blue brie the marketing experts are convinced they have got it right this time the cheese company formerly express foods and britain s biggest independent cheese manufacturer is oozing confidence it has spent about pounds 500 000 developing churnton whose name is supposed to conjure up homely images of traditional cheese making and is splashing out pounds 2 5m on a saturation campaign of television and magazine advertising mail shots and in store tastings churnton is a hard cheese made to a secret recipe in the company s creamery in malpas cheshire it looks like a cheddar but with an open texture and has a fairly strong flavour unlike new specialist farmhouse cheeses churnton is aimed unashamedly at the mass of consumers who buy mild or medium cheddar for everyday use the cheese is being launched first in north west england where 18 per cent of households are heavy users of hard cheeses and will go national early next year the initial six week tv campaign began last night with a 30 second advertisement in the middle of coronation street featuring victoria studd the popular television presenter pronouncing after one taste you ll turn to churnton the sales line sprang from the success of trial tastings in safeway stores across the country in which eight out of 10 people said they would buy churnton again it is deliberately packaged to look like an ordinary cheddar so the trick is getting people to taste it in the first place says maria dooley marketing manager price will be important at this end of the market churnton will sell at a slight premium to mild or medium cheddar but the company has opted for fixed weight packs starting at 99p for 200g when buying variable weight packs of cheese people fish around for the ones that are below pounds 1 says dooley it might seem a gamble to target a new brand at a market which is 85 per cent dominated by supermarket own label cheeses roughly the reverse of france where branded regional cheeses abound and the retailing sector is more fragmented roger davenport managing director explains that the relative lack of branding in the uk is a result of the great success of major supermarket chains and their drive towards own label but any desire the supermarkets may have for innovation is stymied by conservative british tastes despite the range of hand made and imported cheeses on offer cheddar and other hard cheeses account for more than 75 per cent of sales that is why churnton is designed to be familiar while offering advantages in taste and texture he says the cheese company which was bought out by its management from grand metropolitan for pounds 96m only 16 months ago believes there is room for growth in the pounds 1 1bn uk market of which it expects churnton to capture about 2 per cent british cheese consumption is rising by 1 2 per cent a year but is still only half that of continental europe and a third of france churnton according to the launch publicity is the first british cheese to be developed for the regular weekly shopper in more than 50 years with weary determination davenport fields comparisons with lymeswold which was withdrawn in 1992 a decade after a triumphal start he says lymeswold raised such expectations that the manufacturer dairy crest could not meet them and began delivering a product that was not up to initial standards unlike churnton they didn t get much repeat purchasing he says whereas ours is very much mainstream lymeswold was always however successful going to be a niche product davenport is adamant that the cheese will not be found bland by its target consumers there is at least one auspicious sign when lymeswold was launched peter walker then agriculture minister was seen on television feeding chunks of it to his dog bomba gillian shephard the present incumbent does not have a dog

title: ft 10 mar 94 management marketing and advertising sex sense and sensibilities a look at the changes in social attitudes behind a rise in complaints about sexism
body: slapped wrists for uk advertisers accompanied the revelation this week that concern about sexist advertisements appears to be rising according to the advertising standards authority s annual report complaints from the public about the portrayal of women climbed from 180 in 1992 to 536 last year while the number of complaints that were upheld more than doubled from 52 to 111 there is a need for greater sensitivity over the use of sex and women in advertisements the asa warned but are advertisers really getting worse in their treatment of sex and women the indiscriminate use of semi clad women draped across car bonnets or pouting from double glazing advertisements for example seems to be less common than it once was an alternative explanation for the increase in complaints could be the sharpening of public sensibilities on such issues according to caroline crawford asa head of media relations a 1980 survey conducted by the authority showed that women were far more offended by the advertising of sanitary products than by the sexist advertising that was around at the time a decade later about one in three women felt a degree of animosity about the demeaning portrayal of women says crawford the figure for men who by this date had also been included in the survey was about one in five still the majority weren t that bothered but those who were bothered were very bothered it was an increasingly vocal group she says the increased use of nudity in recent years may also be a factor while not necessarily tasteless sexist or irrelevant to the product it is still likely to offend a few people the current wonderbra poster campaign is hard to miss and has drawn about 30 complaints to the asa so far however there are no plans to investigate says crawford the posters are of a confident woman of the 1990s who is very aware of her sexuality and is certainly not a victim she says likewise the recent haagen dazs ads which showed a couple in various states of undress enjoying ice cream was considered by the asa to be tastefully photographed and sensitively handled even says crawford if it couldn t be said to be completely relevant to the product the treatment probably would not offend the majority of people rita clifton director of strategic planning at advertising agency saatchi saatchi agrees that nudity in advertising has increased we re not as uptight about showing naked bodies they are now an acceptable public currency for many what is not acceptable any more if indeed it ever was is portraying a woman as a victim a stupid partner or somehow not in control of her own destiny on the whole the ad industry has to toe the line there are no inflexible rules either for printed advertisements governed by the asa or television commercials supervised by the independent television commission about which bits of the human body may or may not be shown instead advertisers have a general duty not to cause offence how that is interpreted in each case depends on the context treatment and innuendo for example a lingerie advertisement from scandinavian retailer hennes which showed no more cleavage than the wonderbra advertisement did fall foul of the asa the strapline on the poster read what the au pair will be wearing this winter says crawford men wrote in and said i employ an au pair and i object to the implication that all an au pair is good for is to act as a man s plaything what the public does object to she adds is inept and sexist innuendo rather than sex itself humour may be the salvation of an advertisement even if the context for nudity is questionable the itc let a danepak bacon ad off the hook in spite of complaints because it was judged comic rather than voyeuristic the advertisement showed a family of nudists cooking bacon and giving thanks that the low fat product was less likely to spit in the pan than other bacons the trade press continues to present problems for the asa particularly those journals with a predominantly male readership according to crawford there are still ads around with line drawings of buxom women and strap lines which say for example free sex and then go on to say now we ve got your attention lads come and buy our motorbikes the authority got into a scrap last year with a farming publication over an ad for paper sacks a page three girl says crawford was used irrelevantly to advertise the sacks two complaints one from a man and one from a woman were upheld the publication and the company then started lobbying farmers and the asa was accused of being a kill joy and guilty of political correctness you try explaining to a farmer the concept of sexism comments crawford who has some experience as a member of a farming family herself rita clifton at saatchi questions whether this kind of advertising actually works whether it is aimed at men or women clearly advertising needs to grab people s attention the problem is that if you show a lithe 18 year old in a jock strap quite often that will be the only thing that s recalled by women she says unless the product and the figure are properly integrated the product may go unnoticed the mention of jock straps raises the question of whether men are these days as likely as women to be victims of sexist advertising at the very least they may be the victims of stereotyping as an article in the current issue of she magazine points out entitled why the man bashing has to stop it lists the current advertising campaigns which portray men as ranging from dim and uncouth to pushy and insensitive and argues that the campaigns have little appeal to women because women do not want to see old sexist values simply reversed there have been complaints about men and sex in ads the asa annual report for example details the case of the recent britvic orange juice advertisement showing a man with wings holding a magic wand and wearing a posing pouch the strapline read somehow we manage to cram in 12 oranges there were 35 complaints that the ad was offensive but the asa ruled that most readers would appreciate the humour of the image to date however crawford cannot recall a complaint about men in ads having been upheld perhaps that awaits yet another shift in public sensitivities

title: ft 10 mar 94 dorrell to aid investment flow
body: mr stephen dorrell financial secretary to the treasury yesterday raised the prospect of alterations to the tax structure to improve the flow of funds from savings to investment speaking at a confederation of british industry seminar mr dorrell set out the objectives of his review of savings and the movement of funds through the economy announced by the chancellor last summer the purpose of the review is to examine the relationship between savings and investment and to ask how best to allocate capital efficiently within the economy we need to consider the extent to which we are prepared to use the tax system to encourage a wider menu of options for financing business said mr dorrell in his speech to cbi members he highlighted a number of areas of weakness in the economy these included manufacturing accounts for a relatively small share of economic activity the medium size business sector is relatively undeveloped particularly compared with germany there is evidence that it is difficult to raise significant amounts of capital for high tech start ups in britain dividend payout ratios appear to be relatively high in the uk the financial secretary said the review needed to ask how well institutional shareholders which play a crucial role in capital markets functioned investors in the venture capital trusts announced in the november budget will be allowed tax relief on up to pounds 100 000 a year under proposals in a government consultative document published yesterday the document suggests the trusts should be taxed and structured in a broadly similar way to investment trusts

title: ft 10 mar 94 health chairman is sacked
body: mr brynn davies for 16 years chairman of mid glamorgan health authority will not have his contract renewed this summer after a report highlighting serious management failures the commons committee on the parliamentary commissioner for administration the ombudsman was told yesterday of his repeated failure to act on complaints the decision was made by mr john redwood welsh secretary mr john wyn owen a member of the national health service management executive for wales told the committee action was being taken to improve matters in january mr davies apologised to the committee for the treatment of the relatives of patients who tried for 18 months in vain to see a consultant

title: ft 10 mar 94 court to rule on councils
body: the high court will decide tomorrow on applications by three local authorities for judicial review of the local government commission s proposals for council reorganisation in north east england a government decision on the area has already been delayed the commission said it had failed to consider about 500 letters from local interests that were sent before the closing date for consultation as a result an unprecedented supplementary report on the area will be published it seems unlikely however that the supplementary report will make significant changes to the recommendations mr john gummer the environment secretary must wait until the commission s reports are complete before announcing any decisions on the area if the appeal for judicial review is successful the process could be further delayed humberside and north yorkshire county councils and ryedale a district in north yorkshire are all dissatisfied with recommendations which would see the creation of five all purpose unitary councils north of the humber in place of the current two tier system they say the commission failed to consider properly the possibility of maintaining the two tier status quo and to carry out proper consultations

title: ft 10 mar 94 eastleigh choice
body: the liberal democrats last night chose mr david chidgey a civil engineer as their candidate in the eastleigh by election mr chidgey fought the seat at the last two general elections

title: ft 10 mar 94 bottomley role
body: mrs virginia bottomley the health secretary is to take the lead in handling general family related issues on behalf of the government downing street said last night that mrs bottomley s new role would apply on family matters that crossed departmental responsibilities

title: ft 10 mar 94 beef ban threat hits meat trade
body: german threats to impose a ban on british beef imports because of fears over mad cow disease bovine spongiform encephalopathy had already had disastrous effects on the meat trade for at least one company mrs gillian shephard agriculture minister said yesterday she is preparing a dossier for her german counterparts on the effect of renewed publicity over bse on meat exports germany has called for a special session of eu health ministers to discuss a ban on british beef imports mrs shephard said she hoped the germans would withdraw their request because it was not supported by any other eu country the german health ministry said yesterday it would take no unilateral action to ban british beef if the meeting could prove that no risks were involved in importing meat which may be contaminated with bse

title: ft 10 mar 94 num in ballot on new structure
body: the national union of mineworkers yesterday started balloting its yorkshire members over merger plans which if defeated would spell the end for the union s structure richard donkin writes a close vote could bring into question mr arthur scargill s presidency although those campaigning against the executive admitted yesterday that such an outcome was unlikely the merger vote has been brought to a head because the num which had 245 000 members in 1982 has about 8 000 members nearly 6 000 of whom work in the yorkshire area this has led to rationalisation plans including the takeover of the yorkshire area s pounds 5 8m assets to help ease the union s financial crisis a ballot is necessary to achieve the merger because of the num s federal structure

title: ft 10 mar 94 health chief is dismissed
body: the chairman of a welsh health authority has been sacked for his repeated failure to act on complaints a committee of mps was told yesterday mr brynn davies who for 16 years was chairman of mid glamorgan health authority the biggest in wales will not have his contract renewed when it expires this summer the commons committee on the parliamentary commissioner for administration the ombudsman was told the decision was made by mr john redwood welsh secretary mr john wyn owen a member of the national health service management executive for wales told the committee yesterday that action was being taken to improve matters mr davies has appeared before a commons committee twice in three years the last time six weeks ago when mps discussed a report on the way the authority handled complaints about the death of a 62 year old man the authority has previously caused controversy by failing to tell patients that a doctor died of aids until five months after his death and allegations that consultants at merthyr had charged patients for using nhs facilities in january mr davies apologised to the committee for the treatment of relatives of patients who had tried in vain to see a consultant for 18 months

title: ft 10 mar 94 tories on attack over local tax curry s claim to undercut labour council charges by average pounds 129 disputed
body: the conservative party yesterday signalled that it will place what it claims are the high levels of council tax levied by labour controlled authorities at the forefront of its campaign for may s local council elections at the party s first campaign news conference for the elections mr david curry local government minister unveiled figures suggesting that nine of the 10 highest council taxes levied in the next financial year would be in labour councils he also said that of the 10 lowest taxes five would be levied by conservative controlled councils including westminster wandsworth and ealing but labour said he had chosen an invalid base of comparison by assessing every council on the tax charged to households in band c which applies to properties valued between pounds 52 000 and pounds 68 000 figures from the labour controlled association of metropolitan authorities showed that 82 per cent of households in liverpool which has the most expensive band c tax lived in properties below the band c threshold and would therefore pay less than the amount quoted by mr curry in westminster with the lowest band c tax 84 per cent of households are in properties valued above pounds 68 000 and would therefore pay more mr curry said that the government had been officially notified of the precise levels of council tax to be levied by about 300 of the 419 local authorities in england and wales he said that the figures showed that on average councils were levying tax increases of 2 7 per cent in the band c range although the survey is not complete this is nearly 4 percentage points below the amount that the government predicted last autumn when announcing its grant settlement for 1994 95 and may reflect the determination of councils to contain taxes in an election year mr curry said that on the information the government had received labour councils would charge pounds 129 more on average in council tax next year than conservative councils he said that larger council tax bills were often levied by councils such as lambeth tower hamlets and islington which already receive above average grants from central government mr curry said what we can demonstrate is that we can provide better value for money and provide better services mr jack straw shadow local government minister said that mr curry s figures were unconvincing he said you can t trust the tories to tell the title: ft 10 mar 94 balfour wins rail link work
body: balfour beatty civil engineering yesterday won the pounds 60m main contract to build the underground stations and tunnels for the heathrow express project paul betts writes the pounds 300m joint project by baa the privatised airports group and british rail is to construct an express rail link between heathrow and the centre of london the service scheduled to start operating in december 1997 will mean that the world s busiest international airport can be reached from paddington station in 16 minutes baa said trains would run every 15 minutes the project would create 1 800 jobs during construction and a further 200 during operation said mr rod hoare heathrow express managing director

title: ft 10 mar 94 building societies aim to shake off shackles a look at the controversy over the limits to their activities
body: even the largest building societies believe they should get a little extra help from the government to compete effectively in the mortgage and savings markets at its meeting today the building societies association council will discuss a paper on the current review of the 1986 legislation on building societies announcing the review in january mr anthony nelson the treasury economic secretary highlighted for discussion areas such as the limit of 40 per cent of funds which societies can raise on the wholesale markets merger and takeover procedures and the process for societies to change their status the bsa to which the treasury has sub contracted much of the consultation process believes the chance of a full review with the ending of legislative constraints on societies should not be missed mr adrian coles association director general says some detailed changes it would like could be done reasonably quickly as part of the de regulation initiative mr donald kirkham chief executive of woolwich building society the uk s third largest says in fundamental terms the only thing really pressing down on building societies is the wholesale funding limit societies want greater access to wholesale funds where borrowing is cheaper at present so they can offer more attractive deals to potential borrowers for much of last year they lost market share to the banks but for the medium term the association would still like an end to legislative limits on the powers of societies except those needed to define their mutual status one suggestion for defining mutuality set out in an association paper about 18 months ago is that a society should raise a set proportion of its funds from its members and have a set proportion of its commercial assets as loans to members removing the existing constraints on what societies can do would inevitably mean changes to the way they are regulated the paper was tactful enough to say it would prefer the building societies commission to remain the regulator but acknowledged the argument for moving supervision to the bank of england as differences between banks and societies diminish that prospect was raised by the bank itself when mr brian quinn an executive director gave evidence to the influential commons treasury committee of mps last november mr john watts the tory chairman of the committee says it will pursue this issue when it takes evidence from the commission and the association during its current inquiry into financial regulation there are also broader concerns at westminster mr alistair darling labour s city spokesman says the legislation should allow societies to expand their activities but i would be very reluctant to give them carte blanche to do whatever they like as mr coles puts it the issue is one of efficiency no matter how amenable the building societies commission has been the need for changes in societies powers to be considered by parliament inevitably means delay he says building societies don t want the ability to lend in bosnia and brazil the change would allow us to do things in the markets where we operate in the most efficient way possible but others question whether societies are trying to seize an unfair advantage given the protected environment in which they exist and the lack of shareholders to hold boards accountable mr peter birch chief executive of abbey national the former society which converted to plc status in 1989 dismisses the argument that societies are fully accountable to their members he says that most savers and borrowers do not see themselves as having a controlling role in the society when people go into a building society they do so because the goods are attractive rather than to become members he says his comments seem borne out by members involvement for example at halifax building society the uk s largest only about 10 per cent of its 5 5m voting members took part in decisions at last year s annual general meeting even at nationwide the second largest where the running of the society became such an issue that members insisted on a couple of their own candidates becoming directors only about 103 000 of the 3 5m voting members were involved in voting for the board at last year s agm mr david gilchrist halifax corporate development manager describes the society as happy to look at ways of improving accountability but far from enhancing accountability the most likely immediate changes from the de regulation initiative may reduce the prospects for internal democracy since they are directed at streamlining the occasions and ways for societies to consult and notify their millions of members society chief executives are reluctant to concede the point publicly but some privately admit that greater freedoms should be accompanied by more accountability

title: ft 10 mar 94 court to rule on review of councils
body: the high court will decide tomorrow on applications by three local authorities for judicial review of the local government commission s proposals for council re organisation in north east england a government decision on the area has already been delayed the commission said it had failed to consider about 500 letters from local interests that were sent before the closing date for consultation as a result an unprecedented supplementary report on the area will be published it seems unlikely however that the supplementary report will make significant changes to the recommendations mr john gummer the environment secretary must wait until the commission s reports are complete before announcing any decisions on the area if the appeal for judicial review is successful the process could be further delayed humberside and north yorkshire county councils and ryedale a district within north yorkshire are all dissatisfied with recommendations which would see the creation of five all purpose unitary councils north of the humber in place of the current two tier system they say the commission failed to consider properly the possibility of maintaining the two tier status quo and to carry out proper consultations the labour controlled association of county councils said it was concerned by the commission s worrying mistake it will instruct its members in areas not yet reviewed to check that all submissions have been considered by the commission the cross party association of district councils whose members include ryedale discourages districts from resorting to judicial review as the process is costly and delays re organisation five counties avon cleveland derbyshire lancashire and somerset have already been allowed to challenge commission decisions in the high court the judicial reviews for avon somerset and cleveland will take place on may 23 in the following two weeks the commission which is working to a timetable shortened by the government last september must announce proposals for re organising bedfordshire berkshire leicestershire oxfordshire cambridgeshire suffolk staffordshire cheshire cumbria hampshire and devon proposals for kent and devon may also be announced at the same time if severe local disagreements in both areas can be overcome

title: ft 10 mar 94 stress on jobless takes heavy toll
body: unemployed people are 75 per cent more likely to experience a marriage break up than those in work says the most comprehensive survey of employment and joblessness in britain the four year study based on 6 000 individuals in six towns found that in spite of experiencing multiple deprivations the unemployed are not becoming a culturally distinct underclass it also found that they are flexible in the work they are prepared to undertake and have only modest pay expectations almost all unemployed individuals are considerably worse off on benefits than in work but married women are more likely to give up work when husbands become unemployed because of benefits rules the survey covered aberdeen coventry kirkcaldy northampton rochdale and swindon it is part of the social change and economic life initiative funded by the economic and social research council it is published today in the book social change and the experience of unemployment oxford university press average labour costs in manufacturing are lower in the uk than southern italy one of the poorest regions of the european union says a report published by the low pay unit yesterday but the research group says the uk s success in creating jobs has been much less than in countries with higher levels of employment and social protection

title: ft 10 mar 94 mercury to spend pounds 200m on network
body: mercury the main rival to british telecommunications in the uk will today announce a pounds 200m upgrading programme aimed at increasing its capacity to compete in the provision of advanced telecoms services the investment in intelligent networks technology will give mercury one of the most advanced networks in europe able to offer new features such as corporate phone meetings the main contractor is dsc a fast growing us supplier specialising in intelligent networks technology which is installing similar systems for several us regional bell companies other contractors include northern telecom the canadian supplier and gpt the uk based joint venture between general electric company and siemens the german group investment for the first year is expected to approach pounds 20m with new services coming on stream as early as next year cable wireless mercury s parent company intends to spread the technology to other operators under its control including hong kong telecom dsc already has a contract with optus the main rival to the former state monopoly in australia which is part owned by c w intelligent networks are sophisticated signalling and computer systems giving operators the power to route calls and programme local exchanges without having to install software and hardware at each exchange they also offer operators large efficiency and reliability gains the investment underlines c w s long term commitment to mercury despite its avowed intention to concentrate future investment in the asia pacific region it also points the way to future competition between operators not just on price as now but also on the range of sophistication of services as in the us

title: ft 10 mar 94 labour attacks major over inflation rift
body: labour yesterday seized on remarks about inflation by the prime minister and the deputy governor of the bank of england to claim that the two were completely at odds mr john major said yesterday that inflation was under lock and key mr rupert pennant rea said it was a delusion to think that britain had defeated inflation mr gordon brown the shadow chancellor said the prime minister should clarify his precise inflation target and whether he intends to meet it mr pennant rea told the institute of credit management national conference it is tempting to feel that britain has won the war against inflation so we can now afford to relax that is a delusion and a dangerous one too underlying inflation which excludes mortgage payments was 2 8 per cent in january still in the top half of the government s 1 per cent to 4 per cent target range the bank said in its inflation report published in february that the underlying rate would remain in the top half of the range throughout 1995 and there was an asymmetric risk it would move higher mr pennant rea said we have to keep inflation down in order to sustain growth monetary restraint is not a hair shirt but it has to be a habit after all the unforced errors of the past it will take many years to prove we have acquired it mr major speaking to businessmen in portsmouth was rather more upbeat about inflation than mr pennant rea but his comments about the uk s economic prospects were in tune with those of the deputy governor the prime minister said what i believe we are beginning to get is a satisfactory platform for sustained recovery with low inflation mr pennant rea said the economy will soon enter its third year of recovery and the pace of that recovery is enough to have started reducing unemployment meanwhile inflation is low and the government s target is for it to go lower still mr pennant rea s speech marked a departure in tone from the customary solemn phraseology of top bank officials in a candid passage about past mistakes in monetary policy he said at the bank of england we are merely part of the supply lines as such we have the ability to mess things up and our record shows we have often used it
